Speaker: mother
Dialogue: My, but are you the picture.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Ah, Conor, how you look a man.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Have you time for some- thing to eat?

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: No, Mother.  They'll be here shortly.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Your grandfather wore that in his service to the King, and I to fight for the Duke.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Aye.  It is his duty.  All of ours.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: But Ian, he's still but a boy.

Speaker: friend
Dialogue: The fog is bad.  We cannot even see the sides of our own ranks.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I was merely walking by when-

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: ...Libera Domine Animan servi tui sicut libertasi David de manu regis Saul...

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: ...In mamus tuas domine commendo spiritum meum...

Speaker: clansman
Dialogue: He is having the last rites now.  It should be over by morning.

Speaker: clansman
Dialogue: Tonight or tomorrow, it's all the same.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: About the only thing that doesn't.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: I'll give it a closer look when I get back.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: Hope this isn't past your bedtime.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Doesn't have a head, does he?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Just show her what she came for, Tom.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: Come on, this is more your line of work.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: How's your uncle?  I hardly ever see him anymore.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: Didn't look like it came from "Toys-Are-Us", that's why I called you.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Didn't think it was my buddy over there.

Speaker: examiner
Dialogue: Figured you knew more about swords than I did.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Scottish claymore.  Take a French epee, add twenty pounds of ballast so it means business, and you've got a claymore.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Mr.-  Taupin, what were you doing in that alley?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I was walking by when I heard a shout.  Your men came right after.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: His name was Iman Fasil if that jogs your memory.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: He was carrying a Syrian passport and had been in the country less than a week.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Two days ago a Bulgarian national was murdered the same way.  He'd also been in the country less than a week.  What is your citizenship?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Do you make a habit of hanging out in that neigh- borhood at night?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Let's just say that in my years with this department I've seen more than one well dressed business man look for a hand job on 14th Street.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Do you know what this is?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: A claymore to be exact.  You wouldn't know anything about it would you?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: It was covered with Mr. Fasil's fingerprints, but none of his blood.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: All right Mr. Taupin, we'll be in touch.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Ah Steven, it is good to see you.

Speaker: traveller
Dialogue: I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You're a kind man to be sure.

Speaker: traveller
Dialogue: I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.

Speaker: traveller
Dialogue: But I had heard his wounds were mortal.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I don't understand.  Not a week ago your father gave us his blessing.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: So why the crazy talk?  It's a miracle it is.  Saint Andrew has smiled on me.  On us.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: That's mad.  Surely you don't take their word?

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: You're sounding like that mad woman, Widow Baggins.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: Me father has taken back my hand.

Speaker: mara
Dialogue: Please not be touching me, Conor.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I'll not take that kind of talk from you.  From those others below, maybe.  But not from you.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: If you send me away now, Mara, I'll not come looking for you.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: Mrs. Thompson agreed to settle for fifteen, Melvin's wants to make a pick-up at three o'clock, the coffee machine's broken, and there's a Miss Cartwright from the Smithsonian in your office.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Miss Cartwright, what is it I can do for you?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I'd like to ask you about the claymore.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: It's quite rare you know, some- thing so common in its time so well looked after all these years.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Miss Cartwright, unless you have come here to sell the sword, there's very little I can help you with.  Now if you will excuse me, I have a great deal of work to do.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Charming guy, Basil.  Once after beating an army of Serbians he blinded all but-

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: -All but one out of a hundred, I know.  All left to be led like donkeys back home.  Now if you will please-

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: He's too cool.  Too sharp.  I think he's got something to do with it.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What could they hold him for?  I think they're just waiting for something concrete before they haul him in for real.  We should look into it.  He had to have gotten that sword from somewhere.

Speaker: supervisor
Dialogue: Hang on a sec, you did your little favor for the boys downtown, I'm sure your uncle and the rest are perfectly capable of taking it from here.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I've seen nobleman swords that weren't as well preserved.  It's just a hunk of peasant iron.  Why would he be carrying it around in an alley?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Someone should check him out. Maybe a collection somewhere got knocked over.  He has one, he might have two.

Speaker: supervisor
Dialogue: You see that desk?  _Your_ desk?  You see the crap piled up on it?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Give it a rest Ned, huh?

Speaker: supervisor
Dialogue: I swear to God Brenna, between you and Thompson's novels I'm going to get a bloody ulcer.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: You'll not be bringing the church into this.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I wish there was some other way.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: So's playing choo-choo with two high school cheerleaders in the middle of-

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You owe me.  Besides, I'm cute.

Speaker: desk officer
Dialogue: Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born March 16, 1945 in Church Hill, Maryland.  Received first driver permit 1967 in Philadelphia.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Church Hill, that's pretty close, isn't it?

Speaker: intruder
Dialogue: He got him.  He always does.  Eventually.

Speaker: intruder
Dialogue: None of this would be happening if you hadn't run...

Speaker: intruder
Dialogue: We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill...

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Tarmin...Tatum...Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born to William and Karen Taupin, no address.  Attend- ing physician, Dr. Willis Kidell.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: 1945, that strains the memory.  Here we are, Richard Taupin.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: Well, this is a small town, and it was even smaller then.  Most all the babies I delivered were from local families.  Richard's parents were just passing through when his mother's time came.  I did it right here at the house.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Then you didn't know Richard later on.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I've been trying to find somebody who knew him and any connections his family might have had with museums or historical societies.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: Don't know about any of that. Suppose nobody does.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: Poor little tyke didn't have a chance.  Hopelessly premature.  He died a few days after he was born.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: Mother too.  Sad case it was.  The young lady just couldn't make it through labor.  Never even saw her son.

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: My brother worked for the town paper at the time.  He took this picture of the funeral.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Have you spoken to anyone else about this?

Speaker: kidell
Dialogue: There was this one fella.  Asked a lot of questions.  I was out of town but I heard he spent near a full day in the records office.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Just tell us when you see the one.

Speaker: uncle joe
Dialogue: You're never "just curious".  You've met my neice, Brenna.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Number 5, lift your coat up more.

Speaker: uncle joe
Dialogue: Aren't you getting a little old for this?  You flunked out of law school.

Speaker: uncle joe
Dialogue: Don't they have enough for you to do at the castle?

Speaker: uncle joe
Dialogue: Forgers do it all the time.  They take the birth certificate of some- one who died young and use it to get legit I.D.  Usually they carry it long enough to pass some bad checks then dump it.

Speaker: uncle joe
Dialogue: Call your mother.  You never call her.

Speaker: old lady
Dialogue: I don't know.  I'd have to see his thing.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I can't figure out why he's doing it. He's been Richard Taupin at least since 1967.  And the guys rich.  You should see the stuff he has in that shop.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Some guy named Smith was asking about him in Church Hill.  I passed his name around with your buddies downtown but they drew a blank.  So he isn't a cop.  District anyway.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Probably just some exec ducking an ex-wife.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Dr. Kidell had a picture in his file of the funeral.  The father looked just like Richard.  Even had a mark on his cheek.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: P.D. says 41, but he barely looks

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Find the father.  That should clear things up.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Taupin, isn't that the guy Moran picked up the other night?

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: He'd want to know about all this.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Mr. Congeniality?  Let him find his own clues.  There's a journal article in this somewhere.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Uncle Joey's little girl.  Can't get the taste out of her mouth.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: Well, the cream of society awaits.  If you're ever in the neighborhood...

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: It was about fifty yards down- stream from the head.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Both were cut real clean.  Like the other ones...

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: A neighbor saw your car leave.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Look, I don't know what the hell you're up to, but I think I've got a pretty good idea.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I've got all the time in the world.  Except right now.  If you will excuse me, Lieutenant.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: People like that rarely leave business cards.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I think you do.  Better yet, I don't think anything was stolen because nothing was there in the first place. And I think Mr. Smith, whoever he is, now knows that.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Miss Cartwright, you are involving yourself in matters that do not concern you.  I strongly suggest you return to Washington and stay out of small town cemetaries.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I doubt that.  Good day, Miss Cartwright.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: You've been here from the start.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: My quarry grows clever with age.  And the others, incompetent.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: I do hope she enjoys a good show.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Generation upon generation. Tens of thousands of miles.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You're the last, MacLeod. Romirez, Lacroux, Neuvich, those fools that followed me, their heads all line my shelf.  All but yours.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Can you feel it, MacLeod? Can you _feel_ it!

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: You'll be safe here.  He won't kill in a church.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What the hell is going on?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: I am from Spain.  And I would like a moment of your time.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I haven't much to offer, Mr. Romirez from Spain, but you're welcome to what's here.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Your back, it would seem perhaps you were injured in battle?

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: Five years past me clan fought another over some- thing I cannot even re- member.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Your marks would suggest great injury.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: And but for a mark you are well as any man, no?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: I should imagine that your recovery must have alarmed your fellow villagers, perhaps giving them reason to invent an explanation.  And a solution.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: And now you live in a small village miles away from all you knew.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: First food, no?  A good meal makes conversation so much easier.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Hmm, que rico.  What is it you call this?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You Scots have a way with game.  It still has life in it. Spirit.  Back home the food is so...domestic.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: I was sent by his majesty of Spain to Inverness as a con- sultant on matters of metal.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: You're a long way from Inverness.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: In my travels I heard the story of the MacLeod boy struck down and brought from the hand of death by powers not of this Earth.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: You know me home.  Me name.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: It was time for our paths to cross.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Does it change with me in the room?

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: He told me there could be only one.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Some cling to sanity through time with the one continuity and trad0 ition their lives have known: The Game.  permanently.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You are still so very young.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Conor, you and I, we cannot be killed.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Listen to me.  Hear the words.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: This is Dr. Wickland at GWU.  Your test came back today.  You can call me here at the med center if you have any questions.

Speaker: supervisor's voice
Dialogue: Brenna, where the hell are you? The place is full of cops asking weird questions.  What's going on? I've got work stacking up.  Get in here right away.

Speaker: knight's voice
Dialogue: My quarrel is not with you.  Meet me.

Speaker: knight's voice
Dialogue: We have much to talk of, you and I.  Answers for the young historian.  O'Reily's.  Tonight.  I've grown to like taverns.

Speaker: mother's voice
Dialogue: Hi Brenna, it's mom.  Me and your neices just wanted to call and wish you a happy birthday.  Crissy made a real cute card for you, be sure to call her.  Will you be home for Easter?  Call when you can.  Love you.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Three days you've laid there. It's time you ate.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You are not dead, boy.  Accept it.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: This is monstrous.  I'll burn in hell for all eternity.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You'd have to die first.  Aqui.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: What is to become of me?  Am I to wander the Earth forever like a ghost?

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: Then they were right.  I am evil. This is God's punishment.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You have done nothing wrong Conor MacLeod.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: Oh my God.  Oh my God I'm lost.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: Why does he want to kill me?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: There is an imperfection.  For all your healing, if your head ever leaves your neck, you are dead. You can survive anything but steel against your threat.  Then it is over.  The end.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: How can I stop such a man?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Hide.  Run to the ends of the Earth till you learn.  You must learn to defend yourself.  In this I can help.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: We are brothers.  And you are a defense-  -of sorts.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: The money in the estate was enough to cover your costs?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: When may I expect the cleaners?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: That stuff'll put you away if you're not careful.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: There was a Count.  Count Dusan.  He would invite the local peasants to his chateau, fill them full of wine, then slice their bellies so he could reuse it.  The symmetry of that somehow always appealed to me.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Buy a birthday girl a drink?

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Are you going to offer me a chair or leave me standing here all night?

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Head still secure to the neck.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: How many places this side of the Atlantic serve lager and lime?

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Old habits die hard.  Peasant drool, I know.  But it's the closest thing they stock to my side of the fence.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: It is the gathering, my friend.  The settling of old scores.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: And have you something to settle with me?

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Not tonight.  Tonight I have a drink with an old friend.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: It's good to see you, Kahn.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Come, toast with me the past.  To old conquests, old loves, and to a time when we cared about either.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: I'll never forget the look on that Papal commander's face when his "heretic stronghold" turned out to be a rock full of whores climbing all over Neuvich.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Neuvich, the clown of the crusades.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: But then rides up Pope Pius who calmly brushes the dust from his papal cross, climbs off his papal horse, draws his papal sword and asks just what the hell is going on.  And what did Neuvich, dear dear drunken Neuvich do?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Offered the Pope one of his whores.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Had a great swing with his blade. For a Pope.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Good times then.  A man could stretch his legs without bring- ing half the world down around his ears.  Not like now.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I haven't drunk this much since-

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: I love zoos.  Ever since I was a kid.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: No, seriously.  We used to shoot pool together in Rangoon.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: How do you do it, Kahn?  How do you live so full of life for so long?

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: Tasting and enjoying life is the only thing of value we have.  All else is just marking time.  You're marking time.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I've had a few more concerns.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: The pressure only comes when you let the taste slip into your mouth.

Speaker: kahn
Dialogue: You don't run as hard, MacLeod. You just don't run as hard anymore.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: I apoligize for the lateness of the hour, but I'm sure you will all agree the quality of this year's collection is well worth the time.

Speaker: auctioneer
Dialogue: For this fine example of medieval religious art, let us open the bid at 4,000 dollars.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Mr. Taupin?  I have to talk to you.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: He tried to kill me last night.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: You needn't worry Miss Cartwright. I've been at this a very long time.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I left a man dead in Felton.  But you don't really care, do you?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: He's dead.  Whatever I may or may not feel means exceedingly little to him now.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I'm a witness to a murder.  That seems to put me pretty high on your friend's chop list.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Have you gone to the police?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Why not?  I'm sure they'd love to hear your story.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I'm a historian, Mr. Taupin. Only once in a lifetime do you stare history in the face.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Why does he want to kill you?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: He sees me as a threat.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Harder!  You swing like an impotent cow!

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Oh, the boy has a mouth, now if only he had an arm.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Here my boy, from vineyards as sweet and smooth as a young girl's thigh.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: It will take less effort as you learn.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: It's like to kill me first.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You have a gift.  One you must protect.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: And what is this great gift that cannot be seen or smelt?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: The Fabric of life.  The spark that allows the passing of existence from one generation to another.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: If that was meant to be an ex- planation Mr. Romirez from Spain, I'm afraid you've failed.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Come.  Enough sword play for an afternoon.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: You're no match for Scot, Mr. Romirez.  We're raised as riders.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: What is the fascinatioon?  It is only a leaf.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: All living things pay dues, Conor.  They must be respected for that.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I do not think I like the sound of that.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: But why be so concerned about me?

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I am not ready for this.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.

Speaker: villager
Dialogue: Hate to be bothering you like this, but me mare threw a shoe.

Speaker: romirez
Dialogue: Go ahead, Senor.  I have my friend to keep me company.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: I'll be back when I can.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: Come on Brenna, your ass is already in a sling, don't drag me into it.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: All I need is for you to check the name.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: You talked to your supervisor lately?  He's burning up the place about you just dropping out of sight.  That on top of the cops bugging him.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I'll take care of that Corey, but I need this now.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I'm doing it on my own.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: Good way to lose your job.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Some job.  Card filing and cabinet dusting.  Four years in this dump and I haven't written anything for Wilson that a wounded yak couldn't do.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: I liked the bit you did about Baltic chastity belts. Too bad no one else did.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: It's bullshit.  Everything. My job, the people I get involved with, I'm up to here with it.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: You always were hard to impress.

Speaker: librarian
Dialogue: Not who.  What.  Worstick's a town in Pennsylvania.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Chris, have you seen my notebook?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Why, that son of a bitch.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What's wrong Wilson, huh?  Not enough excitement in your own desk?  What the hell were you looking for in mine?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You better have a warrant.  That's my notebook, you've got no right to be sticking your fingers into it.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: I've got a morgue filling up with bodies.  That's my right.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What do you want from me?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Well, the man of the hour that we all would like to talk to about now has apparently skipped town.  And all of a sudden the Smithsonian's ambulence chaser is an expert on missing persons.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: You and I should talk first.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: What are you going to tell them?  That you're protecting a man who's killed four people?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: But there's more.  Wednesday someone played javelin with the cemetary curator in Felton, Delaware.  Some locals spotted two cars with D.C. plates and surprise surprise, they turn out to be registered to our own Brenna Cartwright and the ever popular Richard Taupin.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What are you getting at, Moran?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: You've been a busy little beaver. Especially with that records mess up in Church Hill.  In fact, we're considering book- ing the ambulence chaser as an accessory to murder.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: But we might just give it the 'ole college try.  What with the court back ups, it could be days before you got an arraignment. But then, I'm sure the flunk-out neice of the D.A. knows all about that.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What makes you so sure he's the one?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Just for laughs we raided wonder boy's house.  There was a gallon of one of the corpse's blood in his carpet.  I think it was about then I withdrew his name for humanitarian of the year.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What's all of this got to do with me?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: What were you doing in Felton?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Research.  If your pal was there I never saw him.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: I have witnesses that can put the two of you together.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Don't be stupid, lady.  Your neck can be sliced as fast as anyone else's.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Why don't you wait until it comes out in paperback?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: No.  I had to talk to you.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Is this what you killed them with?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Our cars were seen together in Felton.  They're calling me an accessory to murder.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: There's several bedrooms down the hall.  Take your pick.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: No, that's the last place we saw her.  Okay, will do.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Richard Taupin has become cumbersome.  It would be best if he just disappeared.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I go my way and you can write all you want about the big bad Mr. Taupin.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You make it all sound so simple.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: The only real difficulty comes in changing over the ownership of property I've aquired.  That requires certain records and most importantly a personal appearance at the county seat in Gettysburg.  But that's where you come in.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You want me to front for you.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: The less exposure I recieve around government buildings the better.  You, as Mrs. Taupin, will attract considerably less attention than I.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Not such a bad trade.  The story of a lifetime for a few days work?

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: They lost her outside of Thurmont.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: I want people in here to check over every piece of this stuff.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: We ran down that Church Hill info. She's right.  There is no Richard Taupin.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Not yet.  Called FBI yesterday. Thompson's going to try CIA this afternoon.  Y'never know.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Should have seen him the first night.  Son of a bitch stood there with a quart of blood on his pant leg and didn't even blink.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: See that they are indeed ready, Dupont.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Stand straight, you are a soldier of the King.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Your rifle.  Hand it to me.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: The flint is cracked.  No spark will reach your powder.  You will die tomorrow.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Tomorrow you go to _battle_!  And you look like children!  The General has charged me with seeing that you are prepared, and prepared you will be!  If necessary you stand here all night!  Sargeant!

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: ...And what a sight!  That old mare just kept falling over her own guts till someone finally shot her.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: They're nothing but boys.  It will be a slaughter tomorrow.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: I doubt much can change that. The enemy has five brigades waiting for us.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Won't get it.  We are a sacrifice.  A diversion.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: Eat up Dupont.  It will probably be your last.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: Staff sargeant detailed me to prepare firewood for the break- fast cooking.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: I understand you joined up in Bremen.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: You seem to understand a great deal.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: I am a Major, Private.  You would do well remembering that when addressing me.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: Excuse me, "sir".  I thought we spoke as equals.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: If you wish to play games, Major.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Wait.  I think we understand each other.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Then it is time two of us did. You are very young.  I was once young.  I can help.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: Help?  I've seen others "help". Somehow a head always ended up on the counter.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: It can be different.  It must be.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: Who do you think I am?  One of your freckle faced children waiting to die tomorrow?  "Threaten you"?  You and I just living will always be a threat.  Forever.  Look at your life, Major.  Look at mine.  Nothing there but threat.  Threats and nothingness. It's what we live for.

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Do not turn your back on me.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: You are really going to force this, aren't you?

Speaker: dupont
Dialogue: Either you are with me or against me.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: You see Major?  You are not so different.

Speaker: mulet
Dialogue: You see Major?  You are not so different...

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You needn't look so flushed, Major.  You are quite safe in church.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: State of grace and all that.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: All this time and still a scared little boy.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Perhaps not.  You seem to have misplaced a private.  No doubt by now his head is stranger to his neck.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You surprise me.  Eliminating a rival like that.  Such are the actions of a man of conquest.  I was mistaken.  300 years have turned the boy's fear into ambit- ion.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: I know you very well, Conor MacLeod. And I can see the truth beginning to make itself clear to you.  Mulet, Romirez, they were fools without vision.  It was destined that the board would be cleared for the real players.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: I look forward to the day we meet again.  And I kill you.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You can't stay in church forever.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Here.  The hook should go just below the head, where the meat is toughest.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Fish are creatures of habit.  They like their food where they're used to it.  At the top, hiding in old leaves.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: The estate stuff is pretty straight forward.  Just lots of forms and an appearance at the county seat.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: It will take some time for the forms to clear before you go to Gettysburg.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: No.  So what now?  We just wait?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Well, as long as we're stuck here.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: It's some sort of party the town is throwing.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I thought it might be a nice break from all of this.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Maybe it would do us both good.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: There's a catch.  You're supposed to wear 19th century clothing.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: My father was something of a junk collector.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Here, try this.  I suppose they're still making women the same as back then.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: That's wonderful.  Where did you ever learn it?

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: You'll be leaving the girl alone.

Speaker: conor
Dialogue: Do you have cause to bothering us?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: David, we've already spoken of this.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: He's not what he pretends to be.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: You think you're so high and mighty, coming into town and taking a man's woman.  Well I know about you.  I know about the things you do.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: You'd like that, wouldn't you?  Ask him about his friends.  The ones he meets in the town square. Ask him about the blade he keeps beneath his bed.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: No!  Leave him.  Please don't hurt him. Please.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I don't care who you are or where you come from.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: If I didn't know better I'd say William Taupin.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Your father died some years ago. This is your first visit?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I suppose a Taupin had to show up eventually.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: My father was never one for social whirls.

Speaker: portly
Dialogue: All right, the kids have had their fun.  Now it's time for a little more traditional dancing.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I don't know any of these.  I'll make a fool of myself.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: William Taupin seems to have left his mark.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: And you are William Taupin, aren't you?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: No.  Just the child of some lonely girl I gave a ride to.  When they died I put them in a grave with my name on it. Twenty years later I became the son.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Then you must be at least 70 years old.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: It's frightening sometimes the way you talk about other people's lives.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I hope I never get that old.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I must be insane.  Leaving work, ditching cops.  All to follow a murderer.  A very old murderer, but a murderer just the same.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: I've been telling myself it's the award winning journal article I'm going to write.  But it's not.  It's you.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Hardly a reason to run off with a murderer.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: My life has been chock full of people with complications and weak- nesses.  I can't stand it.  But you're different.  It's in your hands.  A clarity.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: You are a very perceptive young woman.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Miss Cartwright, it's time I showed you something.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I had this room built some time ago.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: That would be difficult to explain.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I was born Conor MacLeod in the village of Ardvrek on the High- land plain of Strathnaver in the clan of MacLeod under the King of Scotland.  On the eleventh of

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I have served in the armies of twelve nations, married nine women, fathered thirty-eight children and buried them all.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I carried that rifle in World War I.  This book is a 16th Century policy report for the King of Austria.  The diploma is my con- ference of degree in Latin from Trinity College.  Class of 1672.  It goes on.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: That's why Smith called you MacLeod.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What could possibly be worth all this murder and distruction.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Sometimes I think it's just for something to do.  A conquest to be the last.  Something to hold onto while everything else around you withers and blows away.  Some- thing to replace the love that can never work.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Perhaps.  There is something more. An inheritance.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You and your buddy make a real team, don't you?  Exchanging eloquent threats in iambic pen- tameter while hacking up all the innocents in between.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: You kill with your left hand?

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: May God commend into his kingdom the soul of our dear departed Jason, son of Katherine-

Speaker: minister
Dialogue: And brother to Howard and James-

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Howard.  James.  This is your father...

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: "Brenna".  In Celtic is means "woman with raven hair".  Only chieftan's daughters were allowed it.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What is it like?  Being you?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Empty.  And fear.  Fear of those that would kill you and fear of those that would love you.  It can never last, and in the end you always end up destroying both.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: But you're known so much. History I'll only read about.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: It's all the same.  Half lives that never go away.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Gettysburg's an hour's drive at most.  You should be back by nightfall.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Be careful.  Don't stay any longer than you have to.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Won't know till the records department comes back with it this after- noon.  Looks good though. They found the receipt in his townhouse.  It was pretty smeared but had Taupin's father listed as a signatory.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Round up who you can and put them on standby.

Speaker: inspector
Dialogue: Think we should call the local P.D. out there first?

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: No.  I want this to be all ours.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: O.K. Mrs. Taupin, that's all I need.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Just take this down the hall to the regis- trar.  Hurry up though, it's near closing time. Most everyone's gone home already.

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Do you have a drinking fountain?

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: Go away!  Oh God, go away!

Speaker: knight's voice
Dialogue: I want you to come to me.

Speaker: knight's voice
Dialogue: Give me an address where I can forward Miss Cart- wright's head.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You disappoint me.  I thought you'd finally gotten over that sort of thing.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: You can do better than that.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: It's from over near the memorial.

Speaker: moran
Dialogue: Moran.  All right, get a patrol unit out there right away.  I'll meet them.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: What's the point!  You have me, finish it!

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: I have waited forever for this. You will not cheapen it, little boy.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: Perhaps Miss Cartwright would like to play.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: I do hope you're enjoying this as much as me.

Speaker: knight
Dialogue: This is nothing that concerns you.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: In mamus tuas Domine commendo spiritum meum.  Auditorium nostrum in nomine Domine.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I can't stand it.  Oh God, I can't stand it!

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: The scream of your blood.  The shriek of trees.  Stop it!  Stop it!

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I'm the last.  Oh Christ, I'm the _last one_!

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: I'll destroy you.  I've destroyed everything I've ever touched!  Oh God...

Speaker: brenna
Dialogue: What are we supposed to say?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: The emptyness.  The years and years of void.  Nothingness.  Bordered only by the quest for ultimate nothingness. Who would have guessed?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Life.  It is the gift and the under- standing of life.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: Life is only life when it is bounded by death.  The inheritance is death. The gift is the finality of life. To be part of the fabric.  The inside.  I love you Brenna.

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: It will be horrible.  The future.  I may die tomorrow or 10,000 tomorrows. I can promise you nothing.  Nothing but a moment.  Maybe two.  But a moment of love, is that not worth a lifetime?

Speaker: taupin
Dialogue: It's taken me so long.  So very long.
